text: [Music]
so the Global Positioning System you
probably have one of these things that
you either have built in or stick on
your car if you get a package delivered
you can be sure the person delivering
that package is guided to your address
using the Global Positioning System
because they don't want to make any
wrong turns because time is money time
again and airplanes use them to guide
themselves between airports the military
uses them to guide all of their vehicles
backpackers take them out in the in the
bush to make sure they don't get lost
even golfers use these things to figure
out how far away they are from the from
the pin to choose which club they should
use so this has become a ubiquitous part
of modern day life how do these things
work well they work because there is a
constellation of satellites twenty-four
at least 24 satellites on each one of
those satellites are several atomic
clocks of the sort that are good to a
part in a million million thirty seconds
in a million years and all these clocks
are synchronized so in this cartoon
we're showing two satellites and a clock
on the ground now as it turns out you
don't actually have a clock on the
ground but for the purposes of
illustrating how this works let's just
assume that you had a similar clock on
the ground and all these clocks are
synchronized so all these clocks are
reading one okay and these clocks the
ones in the satellites are broadcasting
information about what time it is
so they broadcast the information as
radio signals and those radio signals
spread out and eventually those radio
signals get to your receiver somewhere
on the earth now you know that all the
clocks are synchronized right and you
know what time it is on your clock it's
the same time on the satellites clock
but the satellite told you what time it
was but it took a certain amount of time
for that signal to get to you so you're
reading one on the satellite and four on
your clock you know that there's a
distance between you and the satellite
that's proportional to three
okay and the satellite tells you where
it is now if you know where it is and
you know that you're three away from it
then you know you're somewhere on this
circle well that may not be too good but
it's a start
but let's keep going the other satellite
hasn't gotten its one signal to you yet
but eventually it does and now you're
reading for on this satellite the one
that's closer to you you're reading one
on this satellite the satellites that
that's further away from you and now you
know how far away you are from two
different things and you know where
those two things are so you know you're
there and you could probably figure out
that you're not there and the fact that
matter is you don't do this with two
satellites you do it with four
satellites and that helps to figure out
where you are of course you have to
you're in three dimensions so you need
at least three and you don't have a
clock so you need at least four so
anytime that your GPS receiver can see
four satellites you can tell where you
are anywhere on the face of the earth to
within a few meters and it's all because
of the fact that we have atomic clocks
and that they're that good that they are
good to a part in a million million
